properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain continue today. Periods of light rain will linger into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Many areas have reported rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm as of late this morning. Locally higher rainfall amounts over 100 mm are also expected. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T01:59:17-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T04:59:51-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot and humid for inland areas of Nova Scotia. Time span: today through Thursday. Maximum temperature today: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 36). Minimum temperatures tonight: near 18 Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 29 degrees Celsius parts of northern region and the Southwestern Shore (Humidex 35). Locations: Annapolis Valley through parts of northern Nova Scotia, Southwestern Shore. Remarks: hot weather with high humidity is expected to continue today. Some areas may see some relief from the heat on Thursday, but warning criteria is expected to be reached for northern mainland Nova Scotia and the Southwestern Shore. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T11:02:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T19:03:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3012283180.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:26 p.m. CST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a cluster of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This cluster of severe thunderstorms is currently located between Young and Watrous and is tracking to the east at 30 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-24T22:16:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T19:27:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0309525489.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Smoke is expected or occurring. High levels of air pollution are expected today due to smoke from forest fires. The smoke plumes from forest fires in the Chute-des-Passes area may affect neighbouring regions. Air quality could deteriorate if the smoke mixes down to ground level. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If your home is not air-conditioned, be sure the house doesn't get too warm when doors and windows are closed to keep out smoke. Exposure to too much heat can also result in illness. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-25T00:44:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T15:51:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2446298360.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 39 are expected for the next 2 days. Hot and humid conditions today, and continuing in the east on Thursday. Time span: today and Thursday. Maximum temperatures today: 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 38). Minimum temperature tonight: 18 degrees Celsius Maximum temperatures Thursday: 29 degrees Celsius ( Locations: New Brunswick except the Fundy region. Remarks: Hot and humid conditions will continue today for most of New Brunswick. Eastern areas may reach warning criteria again on Thursday before a break in the heat on Friday or Saturday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Maximum rainfall rates: locally 25 to 35 mm per hour in thunderstorms. Maximum wind gusts: near 90 km per hour in thunderstorms. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: early this evening into the early overnight hours. Remarks: There is the risk for severe thunderstorms to develop over Maine this afternoon and move into northwestern parts of New Brunswick early this evening and may continue overnight. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Hail is also possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T05:59:37-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Strong thunderstorms are expected to develop over central and southern Alberta this afternoon. These storms will dissipate later this evening. The main threats from these storms will be large hail and wind gusts to over 100 km/h. There may also be localized heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T06:19:01-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very warm and humid weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing through Thursday for most areas and potentially through Friday for parts of central and the northeast. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 31 degrees Celsius (Humidex 33 to 38), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: much of western, central, eastern and northeastern Newfoundland. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-06-25T10:11:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T18:12:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1580080199.2020

Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-24T22:16:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T19:18:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0452182373.2020
Area: R.M. of Viscount including Viscount and Plunkett, R.M. of Morris including Watrous Young and Zelma
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next 3 days. Warm and humid conditions continue. Time span: today and Thursday. Maximum temperature today: near 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Minimum temperature tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Warm weather is expected to continue again tomorrow with temperatures near 29 degrees in the afternoon. Some relief from the heat is possible over western Prince Edward Island on Thursday, but warning criteria is likely to be reached in the east. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T11:04:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T19:05:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2311460691.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A trough of low pressure tracking across central Saskatchewan is expected to trigger scattered thunderstorms this afternoon and evening. Some of these thunderstorms could be severe. This severe thunderstorm watch may be expanded eastwards as the event unfolds. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T07:59:56-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms will develop this afternoon and evening. Boaters may be surprised by strong wind gusts over bodies of water. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
